We are interested in a review of the taxation system which our Leader, Senator Button, has described yet again to the Opposition, in order to create a more just and equitable system, in order to create systems of taxation which do not discriminate against low income earners and low income families, whether they be two income or single income families or whether they be families with no wage at all. There is a very large number of such families at this stage-families which have to live on the dependent parent's rebate and whose circumstances are completely ignored by a proposal such as this.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition's proposals ignore current trends in the Australian work force. For example, the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on Australian families in 1982 found that 65 per cent of married women with dependent children were in the labour force or wanted a job; that 54 per cent of married women with children four years of age or under were in the labour force or wanted a job; that 72 per cent of married women with children aged five to 14 years were in the labour force or wanted a job. In the face of this clear statement of what Australian women want, the Liberal Party's proposal, which would provide a disincentive for women, particularly those with the opportunity to earn only a low income, to participate in the labour force, is really quite incomprehensible .

Under the income splitting proposal a married woman who considers entering the work force would have to take into account the additional tax incurred by her husband as a result of a decision to enter the work force. That disincentive may be offset in some ways for those with young children by the proposal, still very vague, for a child care rebate. The increase in the disincentive for married women to enter the paid work force would impact most on low income families because in those families women tend to make a larger contribution to the combined income of the family. The proposal offers nothing to single women and women in couples without dependent children. As with all the Opposition's tax policies, their direction is to favour those on higher incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister please table the document from which she has quoted?
—Happily.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASSISTANCE TO CHILDREN OF UNEMPLOYED PERSONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security and concerns the plight of the 300,000 children of the Australian unemployed. Is the Minister aware that social workers in the field regard the low level of assistance to these children as a major national problem resulting in a massive region of deprivation and even malnutrition, with appalling consequences for the future? Is it a fact that, when the dole and family allowance payments are taken into account, a one-child family is required to feed, house and clothe the child for a total amount of $19.70 a week and a two-child family for $20.92 per child? Assuming the most minimal costs for clothing and accommodation are deducted from this, does the Minister believe a child can be provided with a balanced and healthy diet for the $2 or so a day remaining? If so, will the Minister issue a statement recommending a healthy, $2 a day diet for a child? If not, will he undertake to institute an immediate inquiry into this area of need, with the objective of alleviating it as soon as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware, as I believe every senator should be, that among the most deprived people in the community are the unemployed with children, particularly those in rental accommodation. I have never backed away from that; it is obvious to anybody. For that reason the Government since coming to office has done something Labor had advocated for many years: We removed the iniquitous state of affairs under which families who found themselves in such a situation were taxed on their allowances for children and their supplementary rent allowances. Since coming to office Labor has increased the allowance for beneficiaries' children in this area by 40 per cent. I am not saying that makes them wealthy or that that is enough. The Government was limited by budgetary restrictions, as is any government, but within the limits of what we could do we targeted our expenditure to those people because, as Senator Mason said, they are the people who are in the most difficulty. Other policies Labor has instituted in the area of public housing, and so on, have been aimed partly at alleviating the problem in this area, but in the long term the solution is to get the parents to work.

ANSWER.PARA: I am unsure of the source of Senator Mason's figures but I do not question them . I presume that they are from the Institute of Family Studies paper which has been released in recent months. I am aware that the people to whom Senator Mason referred find themselves in difficulties, despite the fact that the Government has increased their benefits as much as it has. The Government intends to continue to target social security assistance to those most in need. As Minister for Social Security, I have no intention of issuing a diet statement as requested by Senator Mason. What I shall continue to do is to try to get a fair go for these people by seeking to increase the benefits available to them and the services available in the community. In the past they have been sorely and sadly neglected by government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Resources and Energy confirm a statement made by the New South Wales Minister for Mineral Resources and Energy, Mr Peter Cox, in the New South Wales State Parliament on 20 September that spending on private oil exploration in New South Wales is expected to double next year? Will the Minister outline the value and details of exploratory activity that will be undertaken in New South Wales next year?
—Just off the cuff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just off the top of my head, as Senator Crichton-Browne said, I am aware that Mr Cox, New South Wales Minister for Mineral Resources and Energy, made a statement about a month ago in which he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I expect a total expenditure of $14 million compared with an expenditure of $6 million last year. The Department of Minerals is drilling a stratigraphic hole at Grafton and is undertaking seismic surveys at Tibooburra. This year I expect at least eleven wells to be drilled in New South Wales, and a big increase is expected in the drilling of stratigraphic holes. In addition, 1750 kilometres of seismic surveys will be made.

Mr Cox's statement is generally consistent with reports from industry sources concerning expenditure on oil exploration in New South Wales. Although the Commonwealth has no direct involvement in the administration of petroleum exploration on-shore, I emphasise that these activities are monitored closely. At a national level, the immediate outlook for exploration is for a continuation of the high levels of expenditure recorded in recent years.

I happen to have, for Senator Crichton-Browne's benefit, a statement by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd which has been put out in the last couple of days. That statement showed that, for the nine months to the end of September 1984, 166 exploration wells-130 on-shore and 36 off-shore-and 85 development wells had been completed. Exploration wells completed on-shore during the third quarter were up 39 per cent from the previous quarter of 1984 and 20 per cent from the third quarter of 1983. Exploration wells completed off- shore during the third quarter were the same as for the previous quarter, but were up 36 per cent from the third quarter of 1983. The graph supplied with the statement indicates that the high level of drilling activity reached in early 1982 has been maintained. Off-shore development wells, the association points out, completed during the quarter were half the number completed in the previous quarter, but were up 67 per cent on the third quarter in 1983. It is expected that this high level of exploration will continue for the immediate future not only in New South Wales but throughout Australia, first demonstrating the health of the industry in this country, and, secondly, giving the lie to the nonsense we have heard from the Opposition that Government policies would result in a rapid downturn in exploration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. I refer to the Prime Minister's reported statement that he will be making an announcement on taxation later this week. Will the statement be made before the Senate rises so as to enable debate and questioning on what the Prime Minister says, and will the Prime Minister announce the timetable and the agenda for the review?

—The specific matters directed to me in that question will be announced by the Prime Minister at the appropriate time, which will be later this week. The Senate will not be sitting then, if I have anything to do with the matter.

—Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to Press reports that the Queensland Premier is planning to appoint a pseudo-Liberal to the Senate to replace Senator Martin after she resigns to contest a House of Representatives seat? Are there any constitutional barriers to such a move, and does the Attorney believe that the Queensland Premier is contemplating such a move because the Liberal Party is full of trendies or because the Labor Party is 'ungodly'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the disgraceful behaviour in 1975 of the Queensland Premier in appointing a pseudo-Labor man, Senator Field, to this place, the Constitution was amended in 1977 after the Australian Constitutional Convention resolved to that effect by inserting a new section 15. In the event that Senator Martin does not seek reappointment herself-and judging by the way the colt is running at the moment it is a little premature to be writing the valedictories- an appointment would not be valid unless the person concerned were a member of the Liberal Party. If the person appointed should be expelled from the Liberal Party or otherwise ceases to be a member of it before taking his or her seat in this place, under the Constitution the appointment would be nullified and the vacancy would again be notified to the State Governor. The remedy for any political manoeuvring of the kind that disgraced this place in 1975 is therefore in the hands of the Liberal Party. If the Queensland Premier were to appoint a pseudo-Liberal to any possible Martin vacancy, the appropriate course for the Liberal Party would be to expel that person. If it failed to do so it would have only itself to blame for finding itself in such a position.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the last part of Senator Ray's question, I do not know whether Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen shares Mr Sinclair's view that the Liberal Party is full of whimps and trendies, but he certainly seems to think that the Labor Party is full of the ungodly, on the basis, it seems, given this morning's Press reports, of an alleged substantial proportion of our numbers seeking an affirmation rather than an oath at the time of the swearing in of the last Parliament. This is a grotesque claim for a number of reasons. For a start, he has his arithmetic wrong. In fact only a minority of the Labor Party-52 to 53 I think-were affirmed rather than sworn.

But, more importantly, the implication is that everyone who takes the oath is a Christian or otherwise genuinely godly, which is a very large claim to make of most of our colleagues in this Parliament. Secondly, the Premier is implying that only Christians are people of integrity who can be trusted. That is a peculiarly grotesque claim from a man who this morning in the Queensland Parliament, quite apart from on numerous other occasions, was guilty of a grotesque breach of trust and confidence in a statement he made on a piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Under the Standing Orders the same protection is given to a member of a State parliament as is given to a member of this place. I think the words which have just been used about circumstances of which I am sure most of us are ignorant-about the Premier's activities in the parliament-are not parliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—Order! I have to make a line ball decision, but I ask the Attorney-General to be careful in his language in respect of members of other parliaments.

—The Queensland Premier also in his statement totally overlooked the fact that some very genuine Christians decline to take the oath because they take the view that there is a biblical injunction against this. I understand that the injunction in question, as Senator Tate has acknowledged, is in Matthew 5, verses 33-37, which I do not seek to have incorporated in Hansard, but it is there for reference. Sir Joh was heard to say that no Christian should vote for anyone who did not take the oath. I simply make the point that that would put in grave difficulty, among others, Senator Martin, again, who is standing in this election, not to mention the shadow Minister, Mr Ian Macphee, in the other place.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I make the point, because this is a serious subject, that section 42 of the Constitution, which guarantees the right to make an affirmation or an oath when being sworn in, has been in the Constitution since its foundation. It was based on an English Act of 1888 which enabled members of the House of Commons who had conscientious objections to taking the oath to make a solemn affirmation instead. I wind up by saying that the nineteenth century society was infinitely less tolerant of free thought than it is today. If honourable senators want to know just how bigoted that society was and how difficult it was for non-Christian people of integrity then, they will not have to go very far north of the Tweed today to get a demonstration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Am I to gather from the comments made by the Leader of the Government that he agrees that the Australian taxation system provides an advantage to the self- employed person who can split his or her income to the disadvantage of the pay as you earn taxpayer who cannot? Does he agree that this is unfair and inequitable? Does he agree with the Prime Minister's description of the Opposition's proposal to correct this anomaly as a fizzer?

—First of all, Senator Archer cannot take it, as he put it, that I said anything of the sort. What I did, in answer to a question, was to draw attention to the inequity of the tax splitting proposals which the Liberal Opposition is apparently advancing and, more importantly, to the problems which are associated with the Liberals' statement; namely, how they are going to pay for the proposals, the enormous cost involved in the exercise, the fact that it does not help single taxpayers without dependants at all, enormous inequities associated with it and the very real problems in paying for it in terms of the prescription offered by the Opposition spokesmen. Those are the things which have to be addressed in the context of the overall debate. Whether Mr Hawke described the policy as wimpish or wet or something like that I do not know; I did not see that statement. I certainly would not associate myself with any of those comments.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the Senate of the outcome of Australia's candidature for the United Nations Security Council? Can he also inform the Senate of Australia's priorities in the Security Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was reported this morning, Australia was elected to the Security Council yesterday for a two-year term beginning on 1 January 1985. The elections for five places took place in the General Assembly of the United Nations in New York. What was not fully reported was that Australia was elected on the first ballot, receiving the highest number of votes among the successful candidates. In fact, we received 146 votes out of a possible 157 in a situation where only two-thirds of the General Assembly was necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: It needs to be appreciated that the 15-member Security Council is a most important body in the system of multilateral affairs, charged as it is with the primary responsibility under the United Nations Charter for the maintenance of international peace and security. Australia, as we all know, is a founder member of the United Nations, and has served on the Security Council on three occasions , most recently in 1973-74 under the previous Labor Government.

As a member of the Council, Australia will pursue actively the search for international peace and security, social progress, justice and understanding. We will also be seeking, in co-operation with like minded countries, to promote proposals to make the United Nations system more effective and more responsive to the needs of member states. The election of Australia to the Security Council is a fitting recognition of the standing that Australia once again enjoys in the international community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Resources and Energy. The Minister may be aware that the Australian Nuclear Veterans Association has been granted legal aid by the Government to assist in legal costs for the Association's appearance before the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia, currently being conducted. Additional special applications have been made to the Government by the association for further urgent funds. An earlier application in July for $20,000 was refused, but subsequently, I am advised, Senator Walsh verbally agreed to provide the extra funds. As the hearings are currently in progress, and the money is urgently needed by the association, most of the members of which are pensioners, some in poor health, can the Minister undertake to pursue the matter urgently so that the association knows what funds it has available to appear at these hearings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has had requests for funds from four nuclear veterans organisations, including the Australian Nuclear Veterans Association in Queensland, South Australia and New South Wales. The Government has already decided on the provision of legal aid to these organisations. It was necessary to decide the legal aid issue and the scope of the funding under these arrangements before considering requests for further assistance to the organisations themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: It has also been necessary to consider similar requests for assistance on behalf of Aboriginal groups. The matter is made yet more difficult because of the fractured organisations representing nuclear veterans. This raises the issue of whether the Government should responsibly fund four separate organisations.

The Government anticipates finalising its decision on this matter and on the funding of the Aboriginal groups for research shortly. I hope that when Senator Walsh returns next week he will be in a position to announce the final decisions in this area; but, as I said, it is not an easy problem to solve with the number of organisations which are claiming to be represented and which are asking for assistance in the preparation of their cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to the Opposition's recently released policy on veterans' affairs. To what extent is that policy at odds with this Government's policy and what would be the implications for spending in his portfolio in the unlikely event that the Opposition got the opportunity to implement its policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Opposition's veterans' affairs policy because in fact it is not at odds to any marked extent with the policy being pursued by me and the current Government. In fact, it amounts to a tacit endorsement of the initiatives that we have taken since we came into office in March of last year. There are, however, two issues on which I could comment. I think that the other six or seven issues that are raised in the document are substantially in accordance with the Labor Government's policy. One could even be unkind enough to suggest that they have been stolen from our policy initiatives. However, one firm new policy is the Opposition's commitment to extend the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. The Opposition does not appear to be aware that last year we extended the counselling service for Vietnam veterans on a couple of occasions. In fact, we have further plans in hand for even more extensions.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there are a couple of vague statements of intent in the policy statement in respect of which I would like to make some reference because, if implemented, they would represent a substantial outlay of funds and would dramatically increase what would already be a massive structural Budget deficit. These are problems with which I have to grapple. Having regard to the Opposition 's overall approach to tax and to spending programs one can only say that the policies, if implemented, would represent an outlay in each and every Budget of an additional $200m. I refer substantially to the Opposition's statement that it would seek to examine further criteria for the definition of a 'theatre of war'. If that proposal were carried out to its fullest extent at least 70,000 people who did not serve in a theatre of war and who do not meet the theatre of war service criteria would be brought into the system and the cost in a full year would be at least an extra $70m.

The other matter, of course, in the Opposition's policy, on which I suppose there is some degree of common ground is defence services homes. However, the cost to the Government of eliminating the waiting period in the first year of operation would be $60m. If we were to increase the defence service loan in accordance with the demands of veterans' organisations from $25,000 to $40,000 and extend the portability the cost would be something approximating another $ 70m. Therefore, whilst in general terms there is a degree of uniformity, there are several areas which would really commit a future government to substantial increases in veterans' affairs expenditure. Having regard to the Opposition's general policies on the economy in respect of which it wants to change the tax structure, reduce tax income and spend money building railways and other expensive undertakings, one must ask where the money is going to come from.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Attorney-General have in his office in Parliament House on any days preceding statements in the House of Representatives by Mr Lionel Bowen, the Deputy Prime Minister, or Mr Tickner the Attorney-General's departmental file relating to representations made by or on behalf of Morgan Ryan to myself for a no bill in respect of his committal on charges of forgery and conspiracy in March 1982? If so, for what reason was the file in the office of the Attorney-General? Did the Attorney-General or any member of his staff peruse the file and, if so, for what purpose? Can the Attorney give an assurance that the file was not perused by any other person? Was any information about any material on the file provided by the Attorney or any member of his staff to the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tickner or any other unauthorised person?

—I do recall that the files were in my office for a period of time over the last few weeks. I am not quite sure precisely when but it could well have been before statements were made by Mr Tickner; I do not think it was before statements were made by the Deputy Prime Minister, but I would have to check that. They were in my office for the purpose of a response that I was asked to make in my recollection by the Senate committee dealing with the matter of Mr Justice Murphy. The Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge, I think, wanted at one stage some information from me about the chronology, the sequence of events and the handling of the Morgan Ryan matter over its whole history, including the dates on which no bill applications had been made. That had an obvious relevance to its terms of reference. It was part of a normal process of processing information for the purposes of the Committee. I have no knowledge whatsoever of the file being perused by anyone else than members of my staff for that particular purpose.

—I ask a supplementary question. Did any officer of the Senate committee or anybody connected with the Senate committee in fact exercise a request to have access to the file when it was in the Attorney's office?
—I would need to check that matter. I will give the honourable senator information accordingly as soon as I do so.

—Will the Minister for Social Security explain the carefully developed priorities of the Hawke Government in relation to the provision of children's services and assistance to the families for which such services are established?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has taken the view that the most efficient and equitable way to provide child care services and enhance existing services is via direct capital and recurrent cost funding to community based groups which manage child care facilities and by providing financial assistance to those unable to meet the full cost of child care. To this end we have given a very high priority to child care. In the last 18 months, since coming to office, we have provided $40m for new services and initiatives-$10m in the first Budget and $30m in the 1984-85 Budget. In 1984-85 we will see a very dramatic increase in the number of child care places because of this funding and because of the co- operation between the Federal Government and the State governments in the provision of child care places.

ANSWER.PARA: This contrasts with a virtual freezing of funds for new services by the previous Government in its last two years of office and a decline in real terms in Commonwealth expenditure over its whole period of office. This additional money will now be spent in high need areas or the introduction of new and innovative services for disadvantaged people in particular-for example, the children of unemployed, single parents, new migrants, Aboriginals and disabled children. We believe that this concentration on the less affluent areas and the more needy groups in the community is important. We will continue to fund in this way and we will continue to have a high priority in areas of high need. I am pleased to see that we will continue to get co-operation from the States to this end.

It is, therefore, with interest that I note, in passing, the new policy announced by the present Opposition and previous Government, which is apparently willing to forgo some $200m in revenue on a rebate for child care. However, during its time in office it was unable to expend any extra money at all and in fact was responsible for a real decline in funds. It is willing to spend money on a rebate which in fact will go to those who are paying taxes and which will be of no assistance to those who are on low incomes or pensions and benefits and do not pay taxes. When the tax rebate in the Oppositions taxation policy is viewed against the extraordinary vagueness of its social security policy, which many people will be surprised to know was also released yesterday, one wonders whether the social security policy was not released at the same time as the tax policy to make sure that no one noticed that it was around. No mention is made of figures in the extraordinarily vague child care provision in the Opposition's social security policy. It is claimed that the policy will give no assistance in special areas. It seems to me that the only undertaking is the tax rebate mentioned in the Opposition's taxation policy. That rebate, I repeat, will benefit those who are paying the most tax and those who are wealthy and is in extraordinary contrast to the willingness to spend almost $200m on child care through taxation forgone in a coming government when in a previous government the Opposition was willing not only to spend nothing more but also to decrease expenditure as the years went by.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether, in view of the action of the coalition parties in now presenting publicly a considered and comprehensive policy on 'Regulation, Deregulation and Reform of the Regulatory Process' based on consultative methods and more rigorous parliamentary scrutiny, he can inform the Senate which of the three conflicting courses the Hawke Government now proposes to adopt, namely, first, to obey its National Conference decision of July 1984 based on interventionist policies and fundamental insistence on planning; secondly, to continue with its recent reaction to criticisms by the Business Council of Australia by creating a tripartite committee of government, trade unions and business to explore the possibility of deregulation in the future; or, thirdly, to abandon its party policy and its recent inadequate response and hurriedly put together a regulatory reform policy to meet the grave burdens now imposed on industrial efficiency and on business competition.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question of deregulation has been dished up to me before. I am surprised Senator Missen has seen fit to have another go at it. We are asked which of the three conflicting courses we would follow, and Senator Missen itemised them as he understood them. The decision to establish a mechanism for deregulation of the business sector was not taken in response to pressure from the Business Council, as Senator Missen alleged. I was present at the meeting with the Business Council. The Prime Minister made a speech there in which he announced that decision. In a prior discussion with the Business Council he also announced that decision. It is now alleged that it was taken as a result of pressure from the Opposition. I will deal with that canard in a minute.

ANSWER.PARA: Before I do so, let me say that this Government in its 18 months of office has been committed to deregulation. If those opposite want to ask themselves for a moment why there is such a regulatory mess in Australia constituting inhibitions to competitiveness and efficiency in industry, I remind them that Liberal- National Party governments have been in office in this country for 27 of the last 34 years. That is why the mess has arisen. In the last seven years they were in government they did nothing about this issue. Our record on deregulation in the 18 months we have been in government stands up better than anything they did in those 27 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even the Prices Surveillance Authority?

—Yes, it does. We have been singularly successful in deregulating the financial sector of this country. We are now moving to deregulate the business sector. I do not know why those opposite keep bouncing up these silly questions. Their record on these matters is abysmal. This Government stands on its record of deregulation.
—Say one thing and do another, that is your record.

—Senator Rae gets very hurt when the Canberra Times reports him as saying that the Opposition has an abysmal record in respect of deregulation. Whether or not he said that, it is a pretty accurate description and I think everybody in the business community knows it. As we are prepared to address these issues of competitiveness for the first time, which those opposite did not do, we have announced the review of business regulation which will now go forward.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Senator Button said in his answer that no pressure was brought to bear and that Mr Hawke announced the decision in an address to the Business Council. Will he deny that within a week or so before that the Government received a very detailed submission from the Business Council, several pages of it referring not only to deregulation, which he only talks about, but also to regulatory reform itself, both of which are covered in our policy? Will he deny that his Government received this detailed criticism from the Business Council on the eve of the occasion on which Mr Hawke addressed it?

—Not for a moment will I deny that. The Business Council has made representations to this Government on a whole range of issues, including deregulation. It made them to those opposite too, and they did nothing about them in seven years in government. We have done something about it. That is the difference. It is a question of credibility, which can be judged on performance as distinct from empty rhetoric.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 October Senator Childs asked me a question concerning Soviet deployment of cruise missiles and remarks made by the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament on a recent interview by President Chernenko. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided me with the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government agrees that recent announcements by the Soviet Union that it is about to commence deployment of new models of cruise missiles represents further escalation in the arms race and as such is to be deplored. The Government believes that these reports only underline the urgent need for the superpowers to resume their bilateral negotiations on reductions to their nuclear arsenals. It is essential that the US and the Soviet Union agree as to limitations on their strategic armaments and the related arrangements between them to be observed after 31 December 1985, the expiry date specified by the SALT II accord . In his recent address to the U.N. General Assembly on 2 October Mr Hayden emphasised that nuclear disarmament is the very highest priority amongst the Government's policies and Australia's wish to see an end to the nuclear arms race has been conveyed on several occasions to both the U.S. and the Soviet Union.

Finally, reports to which Senator Childs refers that the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament had supported President Chernenko's latest restatement of Soviet arms control proposals are incorrect. As the Ambassador said in reply to questions from a journalist, Australia is in favour of agreements to ban nuclear testing and an arms race in space. The Australian Government hopes that it will be possible for the superpowers to resume their negotiations on arms control and thereby bring about an improvement in East-West relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's concealment of its real intentions on taxation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is bringing forward this matter of public importance for reasons that are readily apparent to anyone who has listened to the proceedings of Question Time in this place today. It is quite obvious that the tactic the Government has adopted is not only to conceal its own position in respect of taxation but also to misrepresent and obscure the Opposition's position. It is extraordinary that a government running for office is not, in the words of its Treasurer (Mr Keating), 'running on a reform agenda of new taxes'. Rather, according to the Treasurer, 'The Government has an agenda for discussion on tax reform'. That is the Treasurer who has described what we have put forward as unbelievably vague.

SPEECH.PARA: I will first deal with some of the clear attempts made during Question Time to obscure and misrepresent the views of the Opposition. Senator Button, who was the primary person questioned, was the leader in this push. I quote his answer to one question:
I will look briefly first at the question of income tax splitting. The full cost of that would be $2.2 billion. Even a limitation of incomes to be split at $18,000 would cost $1.5 billion.

Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association came on record this morning with his estimate of what an income splitting arrangement to a limit of $19,000-that is higher than the limit referred to by Senator Button-would cost. He put a figure of $650m on it. I chide the Leader of the Government for totally misrepresenting the position of the Opposition when he put that grossly exaggerated figure on it. The basic attitude of the Government was reflected by Senator Button's comment when he was asked by an Opposition senator whether the Parliament would be sitting to discuss the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which has been promised for later this week, on the tax review. Senator Button said that the Senate would not be sitting 'if I have anything to do with it'. Quite clearly, the last thing the Government wants is any suggestion that the Parliament should be able properly to examine any proposal put forward by the Australian Labor Party. We are doubtful about having any proposition before the election. What it seems we are finally forcing out of the Prime Minister is not a clear commitment on the tax approach of the Government but rather a clear statement on how it intends to inquire into taxes, which is scarcely the same thing given the Government's total failure to indicate in what direction it wishes to take the tax system.

We had today in Question Time-we have had it in Question Time day after day and on the public hustings day after day-an indication that the Government wants a blank cheque on tax and that it is not prepared to give any real indication of where it is taking the Australian people. A classic illustration of this was a question by Senator Zakharov who, as a left wing senator from Victoria, is no doubt against any broadening of the tax base. She put a question in those terms to Senator Button. He was unable to say that a Labor government would not follow precisely the same course of broadening the tax base. Minister after Minister has indulged in great inaccuracies. Senator Ryan was silly enough to repeat the gross misrepresentation of Mr Keating about the effect of income splitting. Mr Keating said that he would receive $60 a week from the Opposition's family tax reform package. Mr Keating, like Senator Button, totally ignored the fact that the policy makes it clear that there would be a limit on the amount of income on which income splitting would be permitted. If we adopted the limitation in the policy which, in the first instance, is $18,000 Mr Keating would get a tax cut of $7.58, yet he claims that we are offering a tax cut of $60 a week to people on his high income. That is not true. It is typical of the way the Government has set out to obscure and misrepresent the position which has been put forward by the Opposition.

I return to the position of the Government. The Government very clearly is not prepared to tell the electorate what sort of tax system it will introduce. The basic proposition I put forward is that this Government is on the record as believing in new taxes. Clearly, on the face of its own accounts, it needs new taxes-indeed, it must have them. Tax propositions should be open and clear to the Australian people as they go to Mr Hawke's unnecessary early election. The question has to be asked: Why is Mr Hawke rushing to an election? We have answered for those who have been asking over the past weeks by adopting the argument which has been put forward by those respected independent commentators in Syntec. They said that the Government will need to have a supplementary Budget next autumn to cut the structural Budget deficit. In other words, the Government has got itself into all sorts of economic difficulties and it is using an early election to try to regain government before those difficulties catch up with it.

It is quite clear that the Government will not tell the Australian people what the taxation position is before the election. We have had a panic- stricken statement from Mr Hawke in Western Australia. He said that if the Government introduced a capital gains tax it would exempt the family home and allow loss offsets. However, he contradicts himself. He said initially that he would give details of the taxation review in the course of the campaign and he now says that he will say something this week to establish the Government's intentions with respect to the review. I emphasise again that Mr Hawke is not saying: 'I will tell you what our tax package will be'. All he is saying is: 'I will tell you how we will go about reviewing the tax system and ultimately making decisions about it'. Somebody else commented over the last few days that if that is Mr Hawke's approach to government perhaps he should be offering the names of those who will review the tax system and allowing them to run for election instead of him, Senator Button and the rest of the Labor mob. Mr Keating said:

. . . We are saying that you can't set down a program for substantial change just off the top of your head. It needs to be reviewed over time and it will take time . . . the fact is you can't make these decisions in a couple of months .

The same Treasurer is chiding us for lack of precision in our policy on the basis that we have had 18 months to work on it. The Prime Minister and his Government in the same way have had 18 months to consider the demands of the taxation system and they are, at this stage, able to say no more than that they will have an inquiry and will make decisions in the light of that inquiry. They use nice general words like 'fair' to describe the outcome of that inquiry. What is fair in terms of what comes out of inquiries of that sort will vary widely from person to person. The Government this morning quoted Mr Morgan as having said to a Liberal Party meeting that he thought that in time we would have some form of capital gains tax. I can only say to the Government: People like Mr Morgan who are principally involved in managing other people's capital may well have a different viewpoint from those Australians who are managing their own capital, putting together their own assets and trying to build a better Australia through their own efforts. There will always be a difference between the managers of other people's capital and those people who have accrued capital for their own use and for the use of the community.

I said that one of the essential elements of our debate is that this Government believes in new taxes. I do not believe I have to take very much of the time of the Senate in reminding honourable senators that Senator Button and his Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, have made it quite clear what their personal views are. We have the extraordinary situation where the personal views of Ministers are known , but the actual intentions of the Government are not. Senator Button has been stating his view repeatedly in this place and I will quote him but once from a specific extract in Hansard. On 21 September 1983 Senator Button said what he has repeated day after day in this place over recent weeks:

It is my view that there should be a capital gains tax in Australia and I will continue to advocate it both publicly and within the Government. I am then asked when I will put that case to the Government. I will put it to the Government at every opportunity that I get, and I will continue to do so.

Again, we all remember the Prime Minister saying in 1982 that they were not worth their salt and they should not be in politics if they could not sell the concept of a capital gains tax to the Australian people.

All of this debate about tax, the Government's intentions and the prospect of new taxes takes place in the framework of a couple of simple realities. I suppose the most important reality is that this Government has committed itself to a very high rate of expenditure and it has committed itself, therefore, to very high rates of taxation. The Government is apparently considering going even further in terms of government expenditure. We had an honest Minister in the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) telling an audience that he had not been able to do everything that he wished to do because the Government could not raise taxes more before the elections and, as a result, it could not enter into new programs. We find that the Government has done pretty well in pushing up the level of government expenditure in Australia. In its two Budgets expenditure has gone up, in real terms, by just under 7 per cent per annum. In other words, the rate of increase in spending under Mr Hawke, under the Australian Labor Party Government, is three times as fast as the increase which occurred under the Fraser Government and it is not far short of the increases which occurred under Mr Whitlam and which caused Australia such damage.

One of the simple realities that is so often forgotten in the tax debate is that it is all very well to talk about the shape of the taxation system and everybody's desire to have reduced taxes, but if the Government goes on spending more and more there is no escaping the fact that the Government must tax more and more. What we have in the Budget this year, as illustrated by the Government 's Budget Papers, is a government which is taxing at the highest level since the Second World War. It is taking more of what Australian produces in taxation as a proportion of that production than any government since the Second World War. We find the twin statistic that it is also spending more of Australia's gross domestic product than any government since the Second World War. They are simple , inescapable facts and they are the reason why this Government is desperate for additional revenue. It knows that it has the budgetary difficulties which were conceded by Senator Button in a public speech in Melbourne last week, it knows that it is not able to do anything which can reduce that burden in a significant way, it knows that it is committed to ever higher taxes and it knows, therefore, that it will have to look beyond the existing tax system.

I think that in the early years of new, high expenditure by governments the negative effects of it are, in a sense, hidden from view. The benefits of the expenditure flow to the people, they feel it and they say that it is good. The fact that they have to pay for it is less readily apparent. People would be more concerned if they realised that in this year this Government has committed itself to an extra $724m in administration alone. That means that the cost of administering the Commonwealth Government has gone up by 16.7 per cent this year ; 16.7 per cent in a single year. That is a simple illustration of the attitude which the Labor Party has towards government. It has the attitude that one does not have to worry about who will pay the bills.

In one year the Government has increased expenditure just on public servants and the Public Service-not on programs for the people directly but on the administration of those programs-by 16.7 per cent. I think that is something which is easily understood by the people. It is easily understood when one considers that this Government, in its first year in office, increased the number of public servants by just under 5 per cent and after two years in office is likely to have increased the Public Service by about 10 per cent. The fact of the matter is that those sorts of increases are the reasons why there is a pressing need for ever higher taxation in Australia and they are the reasons why this Government is inevitably a very high taxing government.

There is no doubt that the Labor Government believes in having new taxes. Mr Hawke and Senator Button have made that clear. We have no doubt that the Government needs new taxes. Independent economic observers have made it clear that the Government will have budgetary difficulties next year and that has been confirmed by Senator Button. There is absolutely no doubt, as Mr Stone has said, that the lemon of income tax has been squeezed dry. It is not possible to go on taking ever larger shares of income tax and, therefore, there will be a need for these new taxes.

I would like to spend what little time remains to me on the positive approach which has been developed by the Opposition. I would like to say that we have very carefully not promised what we cannot deliver. We have put forward a policy which has been cautious and which acknowledges the pressing budgetary situation that we will inherit from Labor. But it is important to note that there is a very significant difference between our performance in government and Labor's performance in government in terms of restraining additional Public Service and additional government expenditure. The Fraser Government left office with fewer Commonwealth public servants than there were when it started. During the period of the Fraser Government, government expenditure continued to grow. It grew, on average, by a little over 2 per cent and that is less than a third of the rate at which it has grown under Mr Hawke. So if we start from the fundamental point that the tax system depends upon the amount that we are going to spend, the reality is that we have a proven record of being more able to restrain expenditure than the Labor Party.

We believe that there are important elements of unfairness in the tax system as it applies now. I know from the track record of the Minister for Social Security , Senator Grimes, that he will get up and carry on about the Fraser Government not doing enough to chase tax dodgers. All I can say is that the great legislative program which we undertook and which broke the back of the tax avoidance industry before Labor came to power speaks for itself. Later Opposition speakers can say more about that matter if they wish. The significant difference between us and the Labor Party is that we are going to the Australian people with a clear framework that they can judge and assess. We are seeking to put greater fairness and equity into the tax system-characteristics which Senator Button says should be there but which he says are notably absent.

We intend to start by giving priority in this area of reform to families with children. We criticise the failure of the present Government to do anything about the spouse rebate, the failure of the present Government to do anything about the family allowance and the failure of the present Government to address the obvious unfairness that a single income pay as you earn taxpayer suffers a significant disadvantage compared with somebody with the same income who is self -employed and who can divide that income between himself or herself and a spouse . We intend to take the first steps towards giving a fair deal to those pay as you earn taxpayers with children. They will, for the first time, be given a chance to reduce their taxation if they wish by treating their income as having been divided between them. This is a measure which will be of most assistance to one income families, although two income families where the incomes are substantially unequal will also benefit.

We also acknowledge the unfairness of another aspect of the tax system. Normally taxpayers may have as a deduction the costs of earning their income, yet we know that in Australia many families have to have two incomes or perhaps both spouses wish to have outside careers and there is a circumstance whereby they are required to undertake expenditure for the care of their children. To date that expenditure has never been given any relief under the tax system. We believe that, in common with other items of expenditure that are necessarily incurred in gaining income, that is a change that should be made and a measure which should be promoted. We have undertaken also to give additional assistance to single parent families to ensure that they get equivalent gains to those which will accrue to one income families and those families which are incurring child care costs.

In addition to that, we have been prepared to be honest with the Australian people and say that there are specific taxes which we will not introduce. We have said that we will not have a new capital gains tax or a tax on assets, nor will we reintroduce Federal death duties. In addition, we have said that we will abolish Labor's 31 per cent tax on lump sum superannuation payments and we will move towards providing a differential company tax for small business. In a whole range of ways we have come to grips with some of the areas of unfairness and inequity in the Australian tax system. We have presented a policy which the Australian people can consider, yet we find ourselves faced by a government which is not prepared to tell the truth, a government which is not prepared to disclose its hand and a government which is asking for a blank cheque.

I close by reminding the Senate that Mr Hawke promised a tax cut for six million Australians. In his first Budget he gave nothing and in his second Budget he handed back a small part of the additional taxation incurred under his Government. The present Labor Government is the highest taxing government since the Second World War.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which has been raised by Senator Chaney today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's concealment of its real intention on taxation.

Senator Chaney took up a fair bit of his time talking about the Opposition's proposals for taxation reform, as he put it, announced in its policy yesterday. In doing so he demonstrated one of the difficulties that the Government has, and indeed the whole electorate will have, in understanding just what the Opposition is about. He chided Senator Button and Mr Keating for suggesting that, under the Opposition's proposals, people on incomes as high as the incomes received by Mr Keating, me and other senior people on both sides of this Senate will receive $ 66 a week in relief in this matter. This problem that Senator Chaney has obviously arises because of the words spoken by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. Yesterday Mr Keating pointed out that, if the $18,000 allowed for income splitting was $18,000 for everybody, that would be the result . All newspapers that asked Mr Howard questions about this matter this morning said the same thing. I will quote merely from the Australian Financial Review which states:

But last night Mr Howard conceded the accuracy of Mr Keating's claim at his press conference that on an income of about $60,000, he would receive a net benefit of $3,270 a year under a coalition scheme which allowed $18,000 of income to be split while a person on $18,000 a year would get less than $400.
Mr Howard said there was nothing new in persons on higher incomes gaining greater benefit under tax changes.

Who is right; the shadow Treasurer-the former Treasurer-or Senator Chaney? Who can we believe? We have a clear statement by Mr Howard that Mr Keating's proposition was correct. He said it last night, he said it on radio and he is saying it again now. Yet Senator Chaney comes into this chamber and says that we have to believe the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, but not Mr Howard, whose policy it is.

The second thing I suppose I should mention is that Senator Chaney said: 'The Fraser Government, of which I was a member, has a proven record'. It certainly has a proven record. That is why members of the Liberal Party are sitting on that side of the chamber and that is why we are sitting on this side of the chamber. This is its proven record: By the time it came to the end of its discredited term of government, inflation in this country had doubled. Unemployment had increased to the extent that 250,000 people had been added to the unemployment bill in this country in just over the 12 months before this Government was elected. Employment had decreased, interest charges were up and there was no equity in the tax system. The tax system contained the same sorts of inequities that existed before. Those had been compounded by tax cuts which had been given which benefited the higher income earners. That was the reason the former Government suffered such an appalling defeat at the last election. Because of that proven record the people of this country rejected the former Government. Because of that proven record the previous Government is now in opposition.

A couple of things can be said about the wording of this matter of public importance. The first is that it demonstrates, I suppose in as few words as the Opposition could possibly put together, its desperation to raise this issue of taxation in such a way as to engender fear and suspicion in the minds of the electors about the Government's policy and intentions-the old use of the conspiracy theory, so beloved of conservative politicians in this country. This matter will be dealt with by me and others and I think it will be dealt with easily. The simple situation is that people in this country will not swallow that sort of proposition or that sort of debate any more than Mr Howard admitted they will not swallow the old story: 'We will give you a fistful of dollars'. The conservative governments in this country introduced the fistful of dollars concept; the television advertisements showed the fistful of dollars that everyone was going to get. As Mr Howard admitted on television and radio last night, that illusory fistful of dollars was taken away in a few months.

The second thing that can be said about the wording of the Opposition's matter of public importance is that it demonstrates what can only be described as cheek or gall to a high degree. To come into this place complaining about concealment and imprecision in government policy just 24 hours after bringing down a taxation policy which must be one of the most vague and imprecise taxation statements ever made in this country, I believe demonstrates great cheek. As Senator Button has been saying week after week, I think the time has come for us to have a sensible debate on taxation in this country. It will be fruitful to compare the reality of the Opposition's document with the rhetorical statements of Opposition members in recent times.

But first of all, let me state the Government's position. I think the Government's position is clear and I think it is understood by most people in this country. The first, simple fact is that almost everyone in this country, of whatever political persuasion-whether he or she represents labour or business, or whether he or she is an academic or a layman-agrees that there is a need for tax reform. The only people who do not want to see tax reform are those people who have been benefiting from the existing system. Opinions vary across and within those groups. In the case of the Opposition, opinions vary from time to time, as I will point out in a moment, about the best method of achieving the sort of taxation reform that I think we all want. The system lacks progressiveness in various ways. It falls unequally and, at times, unfairly on various groups in the community, it is prone to evasion and avoidance and it falls far too heavily on the pay as you earn taxpayers. We all agree with that. I think we all know that.

What the Government has repeatedly said is that it will have a general review of the taxation policy with the aim of producing a system which is fair and equitable. We will look at all aspects of taxation with all groups in the community, with business representatives, farmers, union representatives, accountants and whoever else wants to have an input into this. They will be able to express their views and they will be able to put their cases. What is needed from this review is some determination of the directions in which the system should go and, as much as possible, I believe that these directions should be acceptable and agreed to by as many people and groups in the community as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the electorate?

—I am talking about the electorate. Senator Chaney's interjection actually sums up the whole difference between the Government and Opposition. The electorate happens to be made up of working people, business people, people who have an academic interest in the tax system and people who are interested in the tax system from the point of view of reform. The electorate consists of all those people. If we aim our tax policies in this tax debate at the prejudices of a few people with the intention of engendering fear and division in the community, we will go the way we have gone in the last 50 years or so in this country. We will have a system which is unfair and inequitable and which is able to be exploited by all groups in the community. We will have a system, as Professor Mathews describes it, in which it is not only an effort to get the wealthy in this community to pay their fair share of taxes, but also an effort to get them to pay their taxes at all. That is the sort of system that we want to get away from, and we need reform to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: The response of the Opposition to this suggestion that we, all of us, should have this comprehensive look at the system, is to come into this place and say that the Government intends to introduce a bevy of new capital taxes. Having said that this is what the Government intends to do, without any evidence at all for saying that, the Opposition then goes on to invent all sorts of situations involving family homes and other exemptions, as though the taxes were in place and the decisions had been taken. The Opposition wishes to create fuss and confusion but I believe that in fact it is causing more ripples in its own ranks than it is anywhere else. We have seen this tactic time and time again. As I said, it is designed to divide society, which is bad enough, but the worst thing that it does, as Senator Button and others have pointed out, is that it prevents sensible debate on taxation reform, which everyone agrees is necessary. We have a situation where Hugh Morgan is quoted as saying something about capital taxes. He and I, and most other people on this side of the place, would not agree on most things in this community, but he made what was a perfectly reasonable expression of opinion, and what do we hear? Directly and by interjection here this afternoon he is castigated for making that decision and he is castigated as being a representative of big industry and big capital in this country.

While running from point to point in the last week, proclaiming on taxation, the Opposition Leader and the Deputy Opposition Leader promised daily, in fact as late as yesterday at the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. meeting, a precise policy on tax reform as to what should be done. They promised a precise policy-not for them a review, not for them discussions in the community, not for them the consideration of the views of others. They were going to come up with a precise policy that they had carefully thought out over the last year. They had all the answers. When we look at that policy the question can validly be asked: Did they? What we have is a document which says, in precis: 'We will have a new policy on taxation for families. The essence of this is a modified form of income splitting, a child care rebate; all to be funded by a new broad-based indirect tax'. I have already pointed out that there is considerable confusion in the Opposition as to what the effect of that modified form of income splitting will be. Will it, as Senator Chaney says, provide for Mr Keating and his $60,000 a $7 a week rebate, or will it, as Mr Howard says, provide Mr Keating and those like him with a $60-plus a week concession? We do not know because there is great confusion about whether that $18,000 applies to the lower end of the scale or whether it applies across the scale. Quite clearly there is great confusion. That is one of the problems that Mr Risstrom has when he comes out and says that this will cost only $600m, because in 1981 generalised income splitting was in fact going to cost something like $3.5 billion. I am sure Mr Risstrom believed that the policy that was produced was the really modified form that Mr Peacock started to talk about, not the form that Mr Howard, who really is the one who is supposed to know about these things, was talking about last night.

We are not only told that we will have this new, modified form of income splitting and the child care rebate, all funded by a new broad-based indirect tax, but we are also told that this policy will take priority over all previously announced policies. We are told that the Opposition will make a start on it in the first Budget when it comes in, but it cannot say how much of a start it will make as that depends on budgetary restrictions and budgetary considerations. In other words, we are told that those firm policies which have been announced by the Opposition up until now, and which are going to cost the revenue of this country about $2,000m to $2,500m, will take second priority to this one. In other words, if the Opposition cannot do it under the budgetary situation next year all those other firm policies, I assume, go by the board and only the fist step to this new taxation policy will come in.

When we and when the media asked for some details on this policy, what did we get? A common question that was asked was: 'What sort of broad-based indirect tax will we get?' We were told: 'Well, it will be either a value added tax, a retail turnover tax or a wholesale tax. We are not too keen on value added taxes , but we are not too sure what sort of tax we want to introduce yet'. How will this tax be decided? The Opposition said: 'We will have an inquiry into what sort of tax we would introduce'. I suppose the only reason the Opposition did not say that it would have a proper review of the indirect taxation system is that that would have been a bit close to what the Government is suggesting, not only of indirect taxes but that we have a review of the whole taxation system and the whole tax mix in this country. Then the question was asked: 'But Mr Howard, you said in 1981 that such a broad-based indirect tax is regressive, administratively complex, taking up to about 3,500 public servants to administer , and would add to the consumer price index and therefore add to inflation'. The answer was: 'Oh yes, but this is not 1981. Inflation is down'-which is a great concession from the people opposite, having heard speeches from Senator Sir John Carrick and others in this place that inflation is not really down-'and the administrative costs should not prevent us from introducing reforms of this type '. That is the sort of answer we are getting about that crucial area of taxation reform suggested in this paper.

I have already brought up the matter of the difference between Mr Peacock and Mr Howard on how income splitting will affect different groups in the community. It is quite clear that Mr Howard believes it will save the high income earners something like $60 a week and the low income earners something like $400 a year. He is not worried about that because, as he says, that often happens when tax changes are made in this country. I think he should have said that that always happens when we have tax reform under the Liberals in this country.

If the income splitting is to cost what Mr Howard obviously thinks it will, $1. 5 billion, and if it is to be funded by indirect taxes, this means that there will be an increase in indirect taxes of something like $8 per household per week in this country. Who will be affected the most by this increase in indirect taxes, taxes on consumer goods in this community? The first group that will be affected will the the pensioners and beneficiaries of the Department of Social Security and people on fixed incomes who have no defence against such increases. The second group will be the single taxpayers without dependants who will get no benefit from the splitting and no benefit from the child care rebate.

An incidental sideline to this little farce, I suppose we can call it, is that the Opposition, in this policy, seems to have reversed its so often stated policy in this place on de factos. We have been listening to highly moral statements and pseudo-moralistic nonsense in this country about the Government's intention to allow de factos the dependent spouse rebate. We were going to allow them that, and we have allowed them that because they suffer considerably under the existing system, to the extent of $800 to $1,200 a year in tax. But we are told: 'That is wrong. You should not do that. That is recognising de factos and that will bring down the family in this country'. Although the Opposition will not allow the dependent spouse rebate to go to de facto couples, it will let de facto couples split their income. We believe that if income splitting of any sort is allowed, it certainly should be allowed to de facto couples. But the Opposition, with its inconsistency, for moralistic reasons and what it saw as some short term political advantage, opposed the extension of the dependent spouse rebate to this group, and now finds, as it should, that if income splitting is allowed, it should be extended to de facto couples.

What the document says, however, and what I would like to hear from Opposition members in this debate this afternoon, is that these changes will take priority over the other policies of the Government, that even in tight budgetary situations, as we have had in this country and certainly will have in the next budget, these policies will take priority. Not even these policies can be introduced in total. Does this mean that the promise to abolish the assets test, the promise to get rid of the superannuation tax changes, and the promise to get rid of the coal export levy will all be put on the back burner, or will we still have these promises? Will we still have $2.5 billion revenue forgone in these areas and will we still have to find, on top of the changes that are proposed in this document, more revenue from other sources? That is the sort of imprecision that is in the Opposition's document. That is why I say that the Opposition has a gall to come in here and talk about what it claims is concealment and lack of precision in our document. What this country needs is a sensible debate and sensible consultation in this area. What this country will get from the Government is that; Quite clearly, the country will not get that from the Opposition, if this document means anything at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is symptomatic of the problems and the causes of Australia's whole tax system. All parties agree that we need tax reform. All parties agree that there are severe inequities, both legal inequities already written into the system and illegal inequities through which people can take advantage of the system. All parties agree that no one can understand the tax Acts as they are currently written, but no party can give a pre-election commitment to comprehensive reform because its political opponents would flay it in the run up to this election. It is time we agreed that there be no promises on specifics in this election campaign because, let us face it, nobody believes politicians on tax promises, least of all the politicians themselves. Instead of making promises on specifics I propose that all political parties agree that the next Parliament-of whatever political complexion-will form an all-party committee to implement the results of the inquiries that some of us have spent the last 10 years contemplating.
—How can you bind another parliament?

—Senator Messner may not have got even to the stage of contemplating them. Another parliament could be bound in exactly the same way as Senator Messner has endeavoured to bind his next government, if he should be re- elected. I am suggesting that we all bind our political parties to accept the need to review fully the tax system. We have got the background. We do not need to go through the whole exercise again. We are three parts of the way down the road, but there is not a political party which has the courage to pick up the results of all those inquiries, and to act on them and completely reform Australia's tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what are the real intentions on taxation and that is what this matter of public importance is about. First of all let us look at the real intentions on taxation of the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. The National Party's taxation policies are different from those of the Liberal Party because it is still comprised of a majority of flat earthers who are undisguised tax reducers for the multinationals and do not have much interest in the rest of the tax regime. the Labor Party's real intention is to carry out the bidding of the unions and to stay in government. The Liberal's and National's real intention on taxation is to do the bidding of big business and to stay in government when it wins back government. The Australian Democrats have a real intention-I am not enunciating it for the first time today; I have been spelling it out from the day I was elected to this Parliament-to get agreement from all parties to a sensible tax strategy with long term benefits for all Australians, not just one vested interest group.

Why are we having a big tax debate at this time? Why are we having our second MPI on taxation in a few days? It is because some people in this Parliament believe that it is possible to fool some of the people, particularly swinging voters, for some of the time, particularly for the next five and a half weeks until election day. There may be another ulterior motive, and I suspect that there is: We are having this big tax debate to keep the vital issues off the campaign agenda. Practically everybody outside this Parliament would agree that the biggest issue, which is receiving very little publicity, is unemployment, the tragedy of unemployment in this country, the tragedy of three million people living under the poverty line. Here we are contemplating whether or not we will have a capital gains tax.

Over the next few weeks we should be considering whether we have an adequate defence system. It is a huge question mark that has recently been raised but it is getting no running from either of the major political parties in this country . We should be looking at Australia's inability to educate its youth but instead we are talking tax hypotheses. We should be looking at how to reduce our health costs and how to stop the declining health of the nation. There are many more important issues-far more important than these half-baked half promises that are coming up on taxation.

Let us consider the issues on taxation that have been raised in this campaign so far. First of all we had capital gains raised as the big issue on this election. The Liberal Party and the National Party threatened that the Labor Party would introduce a capital gains tax. I said earlier in this speech that nobody really understands the tax laws in this country. It might be a remarkable revelation to the Liberal Party and the National Party to learn that we already have a capital gains tax. How can Labor introduce something that we already have ? It exists today. We do have a tax on capital gains. In fact-here is a surprise for the Liberal Party-it taxes the family home. For quite some years the Liberal Party lived with a capital gains tax on the family home. There was never a word, never a whisper that such a tax existed. Perhaps it did not know. Perhaps only the Commissioner of Taxation and the people he taxed knew and they did not tell the Liberal Party. However, it has been there all the time. It was aimed at taxing speculative gains and it is a quite useful tax in that regard. It could be extended under the existing laws. Right now the Tax Commissioner, without any support or guidance from any government, is looking at the potential for expanding the existing laws on capital gains taxes. The question is not if we are going to have a capital gains tax but how much further it will go and when it will be expanded.

After the capital gains tax debate the next episode was the Liberal Party's policy, a policy which quite deliberately concealed a lot of important issues. It talked about a consumption tax. Again, that is a tax we already have, so to pretend that the Liberal Party will suddenly introduce a new tax that will solve the problems of the nation is a nonsense. The Liberal Party talked about three options: Firstly, a value added tax, which it downplayed because it has heard that it is unpopular in other parts of the world, where it has been very poorly and badly administered; secondly, a retail consumption tax; and, thirdly, a wholesale consumption tax, and again we already have such a tax. It concealed the amount of tax reductions there would be for those who would be able to split their incomes. Some very interesting things came out of the introduction of the Liberal Party's tax policy. The first was that it became quite obvious that this was an election ploy because it would benefit mostly middle and high income earners-those who are likely to swing their votes around from one side to the other. The contradictions that have come out of the policy are fascinating-for example, the rejection today of the claim by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he would benefit by 60c in the dollar under the Opposition's proposals. According to Mr Howard, if Mr Keating split his income his benefit would be taken from the bottom $18,000. That is fascinating, because yesterday the same Mr Howard was talking about benefiting those who have moved from the 30c bracket to the 47c bracket. How is it that one section of the taxpaying community will have its benefit from the top or the high rate and the other will be able to take it only from the bottom or the low rate? That is an interesting question and I will be fascinated to hear the answer. Perhaps the Opposition has two answers, depending on the audience. Obviously it has two answers on another aspect of taxation policy, the consumption tax. The Liberal and National parties have talked about a consumption tax without revealing any rates. So we do not have the slightest idea what its effect is likely to be. Mr Risstrom told us exactly what its effect was likely to be and one suspects that there is a crystal ball in his office that only he can read.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has a computer.

—Yes indeed, into which he puts all the variables. The taxation items are unknown in relation to this consumption tax. For example, we do not know whether the coalition will try in some very skilful way to reintroduce a tax on the necessities of life, which the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party rejected when it was tried last time. We do not know whether this consumption tax would tax services. The coalition has indicated that it would, but how far will it go?
